kg2text: In this paper, we propose a new method for background modeling and scene subtraction when dealing with persistent dynamic behavior over time. This novel approach utilizes optical flow as a feature in a higher dimensional space to model such scenes that exhibit persistent movement or change of characteristics over time. The proposed method addresses inherent ambiguities in the computation of features by using data-dependent bandwidth for density estimation using kernels, enabling more accurate detection performance even when dealing with complex visual representations like dynamic scenes. This approach is particularly useful for many vision systems that rely on background modeling to identify and separate foreground elements from static or quasi-static structures.

Previous research studies, or existing work, have mostly addressed visual scenes characterized by unchanging or slowly changing structural elements. This approach has a broader term, method, which can be used to transform and analyze data using kernels as mathematical concepts or algorithmic components. In addition, previous experiments, including extensive ones, have been conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of this proposed approach for background modeling in computer vision. Furthermore, research papers propose methods that address scenes, demonstrating the importance of understanding these visual representations.
